comment_text.mn16:2.1: The two sets of five are also found at AN 10.14. The five kinds of “hard-heartedness” are also at AN 5.205, AN 9.71, DN 33:2.1.76, and DN 34:1.6.24, and the five “shackles of the heart” are at AN 5.206, AN 9.72, AN 9.82, AN 9.92, and DN 33:2.1.84. | While this sutta is addressed as normal to the bhikkhus, the parallels at AN 10.14, MA 206, and EA 51.4 are all addressed to both monks and nuns. This is one of the instances showing that the term bhikkhu is meant to include both monks and nuns, a common feature of Pali where the default gender is masculine. Hence I translate bhikkhu with “mendicant”, which is both literal and gender-neutral, unless it is clear that males are meant, in which case I use “monk”.
comment_text.mn16:3.1: “Hard-heartedness” or “emotional barrenness” (cetokhila): ceto is one of several words for “mind, heart” and is functionally equivalent to citta, yet it tends to be used in contexts that emphasize the emotional dimensions of the mind such as here. Khila is said, in the commentary to Snp 1.2, to be land so barren that nothing grows even if it rains for four months.
comment_text.mn16:6.1: While “training” includes the threefold training of ethics, meditation, and wisdom, it specially indicates the foundational training in ethics. This is emphasized in the Chinese parallels, which mention the “precepts” here.
comment_text.mn16:25.1: Up to this point, the discourse is mostly identical to AN 10.14. In the next section, the Buddha goes on to show what “growth” means; with the emotional fundamentals in place, meditation can proceed.
comment_text.mn16:26.1: The four iddhipada are included in the so-called 37 “wings to awakening” (bodhipakkhiyadhamma). They are an alternate presentation of the path of meditation, with a special focus on developing samādhi. It seems the Buddha designed this presentation of Dhamma to appeal to the many meditators who are fascinated by psychic powers, with the aim to lead them on to the higher goal of liberation. | “Enthusiasm” (chanda) is the desire or will to practice the Dhamma for liberation.
comment_text.mn16:26.2: One who has the requisite enthusiasm will put forth “effort” to achieve the goal.
comment_text.mn16:26.3: When striving, one will purify and develop the “mind”. When citta appears in meditation contexts, it is often virtually a synonym of samādhi (see eg. cittabhāvanā, cittasampadā).
comment_text.mn16:26.4: The mind clarified in samādhi can investigate the true nature of reality. | Ussoḷhi (“vigor”) is similar in meaning to “energy” (viriya) and “active effort” (saṅkhāra), underscoring the importance of effort here.
comment_text.mn16:27.1: Yogakkhema (“sanctuary from the yoke”) is a metaphor for Nibbana that draws from the literal sense of khema as an oasis or sanctuary for men and beasts. After a hard day’s journey, a caravan would stop to rest, “unyoke” the draft animals, lay down the burden, and refresh themselves in the cool waters.
comment_text.mn16:27.2: This simile recurs at MN 53:19.2 and elsewhere.

root_text.mn16:27.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kukkuṭiyā aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dvādasa vā.
root_text.mn16:27.3: Tānassu kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitāni sammā pariseditāni sammā paribhāvitāni.
root_text.mn16:27.4: Kiñcāpi tassā kukkuṭiyā na evaṁ icchā uppajjeyya:

root_text.mn16:27.6: Atha kho bhabbāva te kukkuṭapotakā pādanakhasikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena vā aṇḍakosaṁ padāletvā sotthinā abhinibbhijjituṁ.
root_text.mn16:27.7: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, evaṁ ussoḷhipannarasaṅgasamannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo abhinibbidāya, bhabbo sambodhāya, bhabbo anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāyā”ti.
root_text.mn16:27.9: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn16:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn16:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn16:2.1: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has not given up five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed five shackles of the heart, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn16:3.1: What are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up?
translation_text.mn16:3.2: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.
translation_text.mn16:3.3: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:3.4: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.
translation_text.mn16:4.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …
translation_text.mn16:4.2: This is the second kind of hard-heartedness.
translation_text.mn16:5.1: They have doubts about the Saṅgha …
translation_text.mn16:5.2: This is the third kind of hard-heartedness.
translation_text.mn16:6.1: They have doubts about the training …
translation_text.mn16:6.3: This is the fourth kind of hard-heartedness.
translation_text.mn16:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.
translation_text.mn16:7.2: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:7.3: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.
translation_text.mn16:7.4: These are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.
translation_text.mn16:8.1: What are the five shackles of the heart they haven’t severed?
translation_text.mn16:8.2: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn16:8.3: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:8.4: This is the first shackle of the heart they haven’t severed.
translation_text.mn16:9.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …
translation_text.mn16:9.2: This is the second shackle of the heart.
translation_text.mn16:10.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for form …
translation_text.mn16:10.2: This is the third shackle of the heart.
translation_text.mn16:11.1: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …
translation_text.mn16:11.3: This is the fourth heart shackle.
translation_text.mn16:12.1: They lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
translation_text.mn16:12.2: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:12.3: This is the fifth shackle of the heart they haven’t severed.
translation_text.mn16:12.4: These are the five shackles of the heart they haven’t severed.
translation_text.mn16:13.1: When a mendicant has not given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed these five shackles of the heart, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn16:14.1: When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed these five shackles of the heart, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn16:15.1: What are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they’ve given up?
translation_text.mn16:15.2: Firstly, a mendicant has no doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence.
translation_text.mn16:15.3: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:15.4: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.
translation_text.mn16:16.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has no doubts about the teaching …
translation_text.mn16:17.1: They have no doubts about the Saṅgha …
translation_text.mn16:18.1: They have no doubts about the training …
translation_text.mn16:19.1: They’re not angry and upset with their spiritual companions, not resentful or closed off.
translation_text.mn16:19.2: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:19.3: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.
translation_text.mn16:19.4: These are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.
translation_text.mn16:20.1: What are the five shackles of the heart they’ve severed?
translation_text.mn16:20.2: Firstly, a mendicant is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn16:20.3: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:20.4: This is the first shackle of the heart they’ve severed.
translation_text.mn16:21.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is rid of greed for the body …
translation_text.mn16:22.1: They’re rid of greed for form …
translation_text.mn16:23.1: They don’t eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …
translation_text.mn16:24.1: They don’t lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
translation_text.mn16:24.2: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
translation_text.mn16:24.3: This is the fifth shackle of the heart they’ve severed.
translation_text.mn16:24.4: These are the five shackles of the heart they’ve severed.
translation_text.mn16:25.1: When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and severed these five shackles of the heart, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn16:26.1: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort …
translation_text.mn16:26.2: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort …
translation_text.mn16:26.3: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort …
translation_text.mn16:26.4: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort. And the fifth is sheer vigor.
translation_text.mn16:27.1: A mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
translation_text.mn16:27.2: Suppose there was a chicken with eight or ten or twelve eggs.
translation_text.mn16:27.3: And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated.
translation_text.mn16:27.4: Even if that chicken doesn’t wish:
translation_text.mn16:27.5: ‘If only my chicks could break out of the eggshell with their claws and beak and hatch safely!’
translation_text.mn16:27.6: Still they can break out and hatch safely.
translation_text.mn16:27.7: In the same way, a mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”
translation_text.mn16:27.8: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn16:27.9: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
